People really liked that.

The second part.

Now comes in the small resolution that we'll talk about in a second.

So instead of taking 20 seconds, I mean, three seconds feels pretty good, right?
So on a relative basis, we were winning like a lot.
Okay, so that's answer number one.
Answer number two is we actually focused on latency in the right places.
So we did this really wonderful thing when you uploaded.
So the way it would work is you'd take your phone, you'd take the photo and then you'd go to the, you'd go to the edit screen where you would caption it.

And I said to Mike, hey, when I worked on the Gmail team, you know what they did?

When you typed in your username or your email address, even before you've entered in your password, like the probability once you enter in your username that you're going to actually sign in is extremely high.
So why not just start loading your account in the background?

And I was like, Mike, why don't we just do that?

It was lightning fast, okay?
We were no faster than anyone else at the time, but by choosing 512 by 512 and doing it in the background, it almost guaranteed that it was done by the time you captioned.
And everyone when they used it was like, how the hell is this thing so fast?
But we were slow, we just hid the slowness.
It wasn't like, these things are just like, it's a shell game, you're just hiding the latency.
That mattered to people like a lot.
